head.supplied: 22 & 23 & 21 ¶ Helipterum cassinianum ¶ D.C. ¶ 18, ¶ Cephalipterum drummondi ¶ Asa Gray. ¶ ¶ The majority of names of the plants from Yilgarn, dear Mr Tepper, I already sent off yesterday. ¶ Enc...

div.p: RB MSS M97, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.

Annotation by Tepper: 'W.A. 2.4.92', presumably recording the date when he wrote to WA as M requested. M's letter is dated to late March 1892, as the latest it could have been written to reach Tepper by 2 April. 22 & 23 & 21 Helipterum Cassinianum, D.C.

p.seg: Die meisten Namen, lieber Herr Tepper, schickte ich schon gestern ab, von den Pflanzen aus Yilgarn. Ermuthigen Sie die junge Dame dort, ganz besonders, die
Frühlingspflanzen, welche so leicht unberücksichtigt bleiben, u doch so leicht zu senden sind,
Können Sie mir, selbst durch eine kleine Bezahlung, zu einer nicht ganz geringen Menge von von frischen Marsilea Früchte verhelfen

? Ich behielte gern wenigstens von den Characeen Australiens das Material für meine Hände zur Sendung an Dr Nordsted, sollten Sie etwas für die Monographie senden wollen. Eben beginnt hier die Umwälzung mit äusserst veringerten Mitteln, was mir tiefe Sorge u endlose Arbeit macht. Also gehe ich diesmal auf Ihre meteorologische Notizen nicht ein.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

p.seg: Ob die Dame in Yilgarn wohl Freundinnen an der Quellen des Murchison R. hat, woher ich gern Pflanzen hatte.
Jetzt hat es ja in N.W. Austral geregnet. Die Schwarzen würden vielleicht in
Ihren Sohn frische Pfl bringen, wofür ich etwas zahlen will.

div.p:
The majority of names of the plants from Yilgarn, dear Mr Tepper, I already sent off yesterday.
An additional name was included in M to O. Tepper, 5 April 1892. The previous list has not been identified, and no 'young lady' from Yilgarn, WA, is included in Maroske & Vaughan (2014). Encourage the young lady there, quite particularly, to observe
carefully and to collect the smallest spring plants, which remain so easily unnoticed and yet are so easy to send.

Can you help me, even through a small payment, to get a not insignificant number of fresh Marsilea fruits soon ? I would gladly keep the material at hand at least of the Characeae of Australia for sending to Dr Nordstedt, should you want to send anything for the monograph. The radical change is just beginning here with very reduced funds, which will cause deep trouble and endless work for me. Therefore I will not go into your meteorological notes at this time.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in; font-size: 10pt;
font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in; font-size: 10pt;

div.p: I wonder if the woman in Yilgarn has friends at the sources of the Murchison River, from whence I would gladly have plants.
Now it has indeed rained in N. W. Australia. The Blacks would perhaps bring your son fresh plants in baskets , for which I will pay something.
